title: 114_hr2712
content: The Act titled "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes sections on findings, a prospective reporting system, protection of dependent privacy, electronic statements, GAO studies, and an eligibility verification process for ACA subsidies. The Act "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" aims to minimize compliance burdens under the Affordable Care Act while protecting individual privacy. It includes a prospective reporting system. The Act "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" mandates the implementation of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Secretary of the Treasury within 180 days of enactment. This system, to be available by September 2, 2016, allows employers to report voluntarily on plan years starting after December 31, 2015. The Act mandates a voluntary reporting system for employers to report on coverage offered to full-time employees starting after December 31, 2015, maintained by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Act mandates a reporting system for employers to report on coverage offered to employees, including full-time, part-time, dependents, and spouses. The Act requires employers to report on coverage offered to employees, including part-time employees, minimum value requirements, and affordability safe harbors. The Act mandates reporting on coverage availability, including safe harbors for affordability, coverage duration for full-time employees, and any applicable waiting periods, to be submitted 60 days before the open enrollment period each calendar year. The Act requires reporting on coverage availability, safe harbors for affordability, coverage duration for full-time employees, and waiting periods to be submitted 60 days before the open enrollment period each calendar year. Additionally, there is a process in place to securely access necessary information for eligibility determinations for advance payment of the premium. The Act requires reporting on coverage availability, safe harbors for affordability, coverage duration for full-time employees, and waiting periods to be submitted 60 days before the open enrollment period each calendar year. Additionally, there is a process in place to allow agencies to obtain necessary information for eligibility determinations for advance payment of the premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act. The process allows agencies to follow up with employers for additional information on employee eligibility for advance payment or cost-sharing subsidies. Employers can provide updates to the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub on coverage cancellations or significant changes for participating employees. Employers using the system can provide updates to the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub on coverage cancellations or significant changes for participating employees. Employers meeting reporting requirements may be exempt from certain Internal Revenue Code reporting requirements. Employers can provide prospective reporting for a calendar year to meet IRS requirements for reporting and furnishing statements to the IRS and employees. Employers can meet IRS requirements by furnishing statements to the IRS and employees for the calendar year if they receive a notice from the Exchange that an employee has enrolled in a qualified health plan. Employees can inform their employers if they or their family members have enrolled in a qualified health plan through the Exchange or are eligible for premium tax credits or cost-sharing subsidies. Employers can use third parties for filing. Employers can use third parties for filing without affecting their liability under the Internal Revenue Code. Exchanges must notify employers when an employee enrolls in a qualified health plan or is eligible for premium tax credits or cost-sharing subsidies. Each Exchange established under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act must notify employers when an employee or dependent enrolls in a qualified health plan through the Exchange. SEC. 4. PROTECTION OF DEPENDENT PRIVACY. Section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for the use of an individual's name and date of birth in place of their TIN if the information was not collected before January 1, 2014. The amendment allows for the use of an individual's name and date of birth instead of their TIN for certain purposes. The effective date of this amendment is 60 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. ELECTRONIC STATEMENTS. Section 6056(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow individuals to receive statements electronically if they have previously consented to it with their employer. The statement allows individuals to receive statements in electronic form if they have previously consented to it. Individuals who have previously consented to receive private health information electronically will be deemed to have consented to receive statements in electronic form. This applies to statements due after December 31, 2015. SEC. 6. GAO STUDIES. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for advance payment of premium tax credits from 2014 to 2016. The Comptroller General of the United States will study employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for advance payment of premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies. This includes details on data elements, the process of notification forms development, and distribution to employers. The study will focus on employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act, including data elements, development process of notification forms, and relevance of information provided to employers for decision-making on appeals. The study will examine employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act, including the total number of notifications sent, differences in the notification process between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, and challenges that have arisen. The study will analyze employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act, focusing on differences between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, challenges in the notification process, and recommendations to address these challenges. Additionally, it will assess the establishment of a separate appeals process for employers to challenge eligibility determinations as required by the law. Human Services has set up an appeals process for employers to challenge eligibility determinations under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The Comptroller General will submit a report to relevant Senate and House committees within a year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Senate and House committees on the results of a study evaluating the prospective reporting system from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2017. The Comptroller General will evaluate the prospective reporting system from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2017, and submit a report to Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018. The Comptroller General will evaluate a reporting system from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2017, and submit a report to Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION PROCESS FOR ACA SUBSIDIES. A marketplace can automatically reenroll individuals in a qualified health plan annually, as long as eligibility for subsidies is redetermined and changes in premiums and the Federal poverty level are considered. The marketplace can reenroll individuals annually in a qualified health plan, considering changes in premiums, Federal poverty level, and income data. If the marketplace doesn't follow the specified processes, automatic reenrollment with subsidies is not allowed until current income is provided. The marketplace may not automatically reenroll individuals into a qualified health plan with subsidies until current income information is provided, following guidance from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. The provisions in this section align with guidance from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services on annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments for marketplace coverage. The Secretary will apply rules for redeterminations and reenrollments that are consistent with this section and at least as comprehensive as the 2015 guidance. The guidance for marketplace coverage includes provisions for automatic reenrollment in a qualified health plan and maintaining eligibility for tax credits or cost-sharing reductions by providing authorization for disclosure of information and updating income annually. The marketplace must have authorization for disclosure of information to verify eligibility for credits or cost-sharing reductions, request updated income annually, and provide notices for redeterminations and reenrollments. The term "marketplace" refers to State Based Exchanges and the Federally Facilitated Exchange.
